I’m sure Walt Whitman wasn’t thinking of microbes when he wrote Leaves of Grass, but his words were an excellent choice for Ed Yong’s book. This was a fascinating book about how we are not just singularly human beings but also filled with organisms which influence who we are and how we are able to function in this world. The other reviewers on Goodreads gave excellent overviews of this book. I could not add anything to match their erudite writings. Suffice to say, this book changed the way I looked at the world. It will go on my To Be Read Again shelf because it's a book that I could open to any page and be reminded how we are interwoven with the microscopic life forms around and within us.

I learned a lot! As clearly written and as engaging as any general science book can be. Maybe a few too many corny jokes, but even those are endearing. Biggest problem was the tremendous amount of vivisection described very cavalierly; this book is largely about the results of animal research and isn't remotely concerned with the ethics of that.Even the narrative mindset is way too human-centric for me. Example that made me boggle the most: frog-killing fungus epidemic is described as terrible for "frog lovers" rather than for terrible for frogs. Oh, many of the endnotes are well worth reading! Lots of little enlightening and entertaining tidbits mixed in with the drier stuff.

This is a very interesting book, but most of it is "interesting" in the sense of providing a laundry list of facts that make you go "hmm...neat!" I liked the book, but frankly it wasn't until the last three chapters that I found a narrative. Perhaps that is because I am less interested in a collection of facts about what we do and do not (more the latter than the former) about microbes, and more interested in how this translates into practical application. I wouldn't recommend listening to this one in audiobook. You will feel more like someone is reading you a list than someone is telling you about story, and thus I think it loses some of its wonder.

This fascinating and informative book by the acclaimed British science writer Ed Yong explores the symbiotic relationships between microorganisms and more advanced life forms, including humans, and how these beneficial and sometimes harmful interactions affect our bodies' health and ability to function effectively, and the features that allow pathogenic species to colonize and infect us. Yong describes historical studies of these relationships, along with current research that could potentially transform how we treat infections such as elephantiasis, river blindness and Clostridium difficile colitis in humans and similar devastating ones in other species.

I very interesting and informative overview about symbiotic microbes. Yong has a gift for science writing, he neatly conveys complex information in a compulsively readable format. He also covers all types of symbiotic relationships from the very simple single-cell organisms and their one symbiotic bacteria to the human gut with its myriad microbial population. Recommended for everyone, particularly fans of David Quammen. (Aside: more pictures!! Why are there never enough pictures?) Also, many thanks to his US editors for not "Americanizing" Yong's British English.

Excellent! Even though I was familiar with a lot of the material, Ed Yong's presentation kept me engaged. Like Mary Roach and Sam Kean, Yong has a gift for making science interesting and accessible for the layman. You'll learn about why grocery store probiotics are worthless, how microbes may help with autism, and what re-poopulation entails. Highly recommended in print or audiobook.

This book is an exhaustive look at microbes. It's fascinating! We hear a lot about microbiomes and such lately, but this book looks beyond human guts to explore how microbes shape the lives of animals, humans, buildings, plants, and ocean life. I learned a was thoroughly amazed many times while reading this book.

there were moments of awesomeness but also moments of detail bogging down the writing. Somewhat unavoidable in science writing but if The Emperor of All Maladies is the gold standard in the genre (of beautiful and clear description of complex concepts) this falls short. Still learning about the complex relationships between our microbes and us was super fascinating.

One of those books which could be condensed, quite effectively, into an excellent magazine article. Unfortunately, Yong decided against that and wrote this poorly organized volume that seems to state the same few facts many times over.
This is one of the best books I have read this year, maybe the best. Loved every minute of it.
7 -- so very interesting!
A beautifully written science book!!! Very interesting!!!

Individuality is a cherished trait of sagacious beings. Man is the only such animal which is conscious of its self. Man stands alone in his mental transactions with the outside world. This aloofness is way off the true state of things. Very small microbes and other inanimate objects thrive in our body and are present in very large numbers on all our body parts. The presence of microbes is thought to be a bad thing in routine awareness sermons, but this is not necessarily so. Microbes are beneficial or neutral to us on most of the occasions and provide immense service to us. They keep our guts healthy, calibrate our immune systems, make us less sensitive to allergens and can even exert influence on our brains. This horde of microbes in our body makes each individual human being a multitude which acts in tandem to work as a symbiotic whole. Ed Yong is an award-winning science writer who regularly contributes to leading journals and scientific publications.The author makes a brilliant comparison scheme to present the contrast between life forms almost perennially lived on earth against others who are relatively latecomers to the party of life. He equates our planet’s entire life to a human year in which the present is just before midnight on December 31. On such a scale, the entry of humans was just half an hour ago, at 11.30 pm, while microbes ruled the globe between the months of March to October, that is, between their entry and the advent of higher organisms. This ingenuous example clarifies all doubts on the antiquity of microbes as compared to mammals or other higher forms of life.Microbes are everywhere, but due to the very small size of them, they remained invisible to mankind till the seventeenth century. It was then Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a pioneering lens-maker in Holland, witnessed these organisms everywhere – in water, in hand tools, in his body, home and everywhere! For a time, others couldn’t make lenses with the resolving power as Leeuwenhoek’s, but when at last they did, the scholars were shocked to find themselves colonized by these microbes. It took nearly another century to distinguish the good from the bad. Many microbes live in symbiosis with their hosts. It can also be said that microbes help us become what we are by modifying the genes of parent organisms in subtle ways. Biologists have experimentally demonstrated that organisms that live in sterile Lab-like environments where the microbes are strictly controlled suffer growth problems in the absence of friendly bacteria. Yong includes examples where the microbes affect the growth of brain. Specific strains of bacteria can be encouraged with the help of probiotics (the reverse process as antibiotics). Lack of exposure to symbiotic microbes had resulted in depression and anxiety in the hosts.The book argues that the sharp distinction between good and bad microbes is an oversimplification. Even the good ones create life-threatening situations when their position is changed, say from the gut to the blood stream. Mitochondria are present in every mammal cell, which generates the energy the cell so dearly needs. Scientists presume that mitochondria were independent microbes in the beginning of life and later settled inside the animal cell in a case of mutually beneficial symbiosis. Even with a history of living together for billions of years, if the mitochondrion is to enter the blood stream somehow, the immune system of the host attacks it with vigour as if it was a foreign particle and not a part of its own body. Yong presents the case of Helicobacter pylori, the bacterium in our gut that causes ulcer and stomach cancer. A very bad guy, obviously. But what will happen if we kill all of them in our guts? Scientists warn that we are in for more trouble, as these bacteria also protects against oesophageal cancer! Needless to say, babies nurtured with bottled milk don’t develop this familiarity of the immune system to microbes. It talked about a system of gene transfer which is horizontal, that is, from one individual to another without any reproductive act called Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT). This differed with the vertical scheme Darwin had in mind, that is, from parent to offspring. The devil was in the details, and if you had read the whole article, it emphasized Darwin’s theorem rather than upsetting it. But for those who judge a book by its cover, it presented an avoidable opportunity to score on the supposed ‘error’ in Darwinism. HGT is widely seen in the world of microbes. Yong presents the curious case of the ‘nori’ seaweed that is a delicacy in Japan. Humans normally can’t digest the seaweed as the gut bacteria are unable to process them. But those who ate them first ingested marine bacteria skilled in the job. It exchanged genes with normal gut bacteria and entered its genome. If you’ve already read books like Martin Blaser’s Missing Microbes, a lot of this info won’t be new to you. However, Ed Yong’s enthusiasm and wider range — dipping into the microbes of other animals and even insects — is a joy. He also provides a counterpoint to some of Blaser’s more hysterical ideas about the loss of microbes. He agrees that microbes are important, and that our relationships with them are complex. But he doesn’t accept that we’re totally doomed. There’s tons of research into repopulating our guts with beneficial microbes, prebiotics and probiotics. No doubt things are in the pipeline which will make a difference.Yong is significantly less hopeful about the potential of procedures like faecal transplants — though the results have been encouraging in cases of C. difficile infections, the potential for treating inflammatory bowel disease seems more limited. It’s not impossible that a refined version of faecal transplants can help to rebalance the irritated and inflamed gut systems of people who suffer from inflammatory bowel diseases… but so far, the data isn’t there.With his enthusiasm and interest, Yong makes me want to hurry the heck up, get my biology degree, and get stuck into researching on exactly these topics. One thing is for sure: our microbiome is incredibly important, and we need more research. Our gut microbes can affect our overall health in so many ways — mental health included — that I foresee a lot more time being spent on this in labs in the near future. And I hope I’ll be one of the people working in one of those labs.If you don’t know much about microbes, fear not: Yong’s writing is clear and accessible, with no technobabble. I think this book would be totally accessible to anyone with an interest.Originally reviewed on my blog.

My favorite parts of this book are when Ed Yong talks about the human microbiome. It's not that I don't want to learn about the bacteria on and in bugs and hyenas and such, but I read this book, hoping to learn more about how microbes affect humans, positively and/or negatively. I was hoping for more discussion of pathogens and illness. That's just where my fascination lies. Yong says in the Afterword that his goal in writing this book was to look at the microbiome as a whole and NOT focus on humans, so he did a great job of that. He makes it clear that bacteria are important to all life, not just to humans. Because, after all, there was life way before we humans were created, and there are many more non-human creatures than human ones on our planet. Besides, it's a more holistic view of life, a "grander view," if you will, than we usually have. I recommend this book because it's eyeopening and educational. I learned a lot about microbes but also about life in general. It's funny and interesting. Yong has a unique voice, complete with corny jokes and wording, which makes this book about microbes accessible to anyone with an interest in the subject. My dad and I read this book together. From a quote in an early chapter until today, upon finishing, my dad kept bugging (pun intended) me about getting him a shirt that says, "Microbe Lives Matter." Maybe I'll just get him the shirt, so he'll stop pest-ering me. But, really. He wants a shirt that says that...

I picked up I Contain Multitudes in the close proximity after finishing Gut: The Inside Story of Our Body’s Most Underrated Organ by Giulia Enders, which too heavily relied on our harmonious existence with bacteria as its main topic. Naturally, I will draw parallels.Ed Yong's goal in this book appears to be proving that our symbiosis with microbes is rooted in our origins, and while many commercial products might tell us otherwise, is absolutely necessary for our healthy lives. From the very first signs of life billions of years ago to modern day, microbes have essentially been dictating the rules by which complex beings evolve, absorb nutrients, battle toxins, and communicate with others. It is not always an easy coexistence, but like a pair of old roommates, we learn to feed off each other's best qualities.Read the rest of the review on: Chaika Books

Holy crap I learnt a lot reading this book - too much in fact, there is no way I'm going to fully remember all the details from I contain Multitudes. I consider this a must read for anyone who thinks of bacteria as being evil 'germs'. Learning about the interactions and symbiosis of the little buggers is rationale enough for reading the book. I also really liked Yong's explanation of the gut brain microbiome connections, explained in an easy to grasp way without over-simplifying the controversies.
"Animals might be evolution's icing, but bacteria are really the cake."

I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life by Ed Yong dives into the wonderful and often misunderstood field of microbiology. Yong will unravel discoveries and knock down conspiracies — all while talking about microbes! Microbes will never be the same once you have read this book. The myriad microbes in our bodies are collectively known as the microbiome or microbiota. Microbes are a big part of our lives. According to Yong, our oxygen is produced by photosynthetic microbes in the ocean and the bacteria in chloroplasts (we would not be here without them!). Though most cast microbes as antagonists, "[t]here are fewer than 100 species of bacteria that cause infectious diseases in humans"(11). Our microbes also supplement our body cells. It carries a whopping 500 times more genes than your cells. What your body cells cannot do, your microbes are most likely capable of.  We then dive into a crash course on microbiology's history. While looking through his microscope, the famous lens maker, Antony van Leeuwenhoek, found vast populations of microbes which he christened "animalcules." The field of microbiology made no significant advances until the nineteenth century, when Louis Pasteur proposed that microbes could be the agents of disease. Before then, disease was thought to be "caused by bad air, or miasma, released from rotting matter"(32). Another breakthrough was seen when Joseph Lister introduced the use of antiseptic for medical purposes. The classification of microbes was enhanced by Carl Woese. In different bacterial samples, he found a common molecule called 16S rRNA. A discovery was made when Woese studied methanogens: "when he looked at its 16S rRNA, he realized it was decidedly un-bacterial"(41). The methanogens were later reclassified as archaea. What marked this as a monumental step for biology in general was Woese's method of "comparing genes to work out how species are related to each other"(41). This opened the path to metagenomics. Later scientist were able to "extract the DNA from all local microbes, cut it into small fragments, and sequence them together"(43).  According to tests done on sterilized mice, "microbes activated a wide range of mouse genes" and "told them how to use their own genes to make a healthy gut"(54). Microbes also "stimulate the production of pro-inflammatory cells, while others induce dove-like anti-inflammatory cells … they allow us to react to threats without overreacting"(64). Without this equilibrium, we would not be able to respond to harmful threats while overreacting to harmless one. Yong notes the irony of this. While many think of our immune system as a defense that destroys microbes, "microbes craft and tune our immune system in the first place!"(64). When research showed that microbes affect the brain and behavior, scientists experimented on sterilized mice and "by swapping the bacteria in the animal's guts … also swapped part of their personalities"(72). Microbes even release a chemical called dopamine, which inhibits satisfaction. By releasing dopamine when you eat certain foods, microbes can potentially hone your diet to benefit them. Sadly, our little friends can turn on us sometimes. Many viruses actually control the microbes in your body which have gone rogue. These are called microphages: "When they touch down on a bacterium, they inject their DNA and turn the microbes into a factory for making more phages"(89). Our immune system helps us control our microbes: "It's more about balance and good management than defence and destruction"(91).  Yong describes our immune system as an "immunostat." When relaxed, it can encourage invasions from outside microbes. When intensified, the immune system attacks harmless microbes and cause inflammation. With our modern sanitation, Yong claims that we have tuned our "immunostats" to be set toward the latter. This inadvertently induces problems such as allergies. The lack of fiber in modern diets also affect our intense "immunostat." When microbes break down bacteria, a chemical called short fatty acid (SCFA) is produced. These galvanize an increase in our anti-inflammatory cells. Fibers also encourage the colonization of helpful microbes with certain digestive enzymes. Our modern world has "cut off routes by which microbes reach us, and then starve those that make it"(125). We then use the microbes' own weaponry, antibiotics, to kill both harmful and helpful microbes. Without a healthy microbiome, many pathogens can easily penetrate our body. But Yong does not suggest that antibiotics never be utilized; instead, he warns of their overuse which "disrupts our microbiome and foments the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria"(128).  Microbes also utilize the special power of horizontal gene transfers (HGTs). All microbes are able to transmit genes to one another. There is a scary aspect to this. Microbes with mutations that allow them to be resistant to antibiotics can transfer its genes to other microbes, making them antibiotic-resistant. Yong describes this as "one of the greatest public health threats of the twenty-first century"(192). But, as with all things, we can harness HGT for our benefit. Yong illustrates this through nori. Nori, which contains special carbohydrates, cannot be digested by regular enzymes. But marine Zobellia can digest it! When nori was eaten raw, Zobellia found on the nori was also eaten. As the Zobellia passed through the gut, it transferred its genes to other microbes. This is why many Japanese are able to digest nori. So hypothetically, if we need some benefit a microbe has, we just need it to pass through our body and allow it to carry out HGT.  Yong imagines an à la carte future , where scientists can equip microbes with specific genes. Scientists could program the microbes to eliminate certain harmful substances. This is the wonderful future of synthetic biology: Synthetic biologist aren't limited to sending microbes after pathogens. They might also train their creations to eliminate cancer cells or convert toxins into medicines. (239) In this book, Yong takes readers on a fascinating ride through the history and application of microbiology. It contains compelling anecdotes which are sprinkled with a topping of information. For readers interested in how microbes affect our lives, Ed Yong's I Contain Multitudes is the book to devour.

There is a scientific revolution happening right now that is changing how we think about living things, including ourselves. The new realization is that the world is dominated by organisms too small to see. Put another way, large organisms like us are passengers, not drivers, despite our egotistical assumptions to the contrary. The subtitle of Yong’s new book, “the Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life,” exactly captures the thrill of these microbiome studies. A microbiome comprises the microscopic organisms associated with an organism or ecosystem. We are learning that the living things we can see are dominated by, and cannot exist without, their microbiomes We are also learning that microbiomes are far more complicated and ubiquitous than we ever imagined. Here are some examples. All oxygen on earth comes from bacteria—most of it directly from oceanic algae, but some from molecular devices in plants that have descended from bacteria that invaded the plant ancestors long ago. Bacteria exist everywhere we have looked—miles down in solid rock, in boiling water, deep in the black ocean, in NASA “clean rooms,” in “sterile” hospitals, in insects, plants, soil, air, and of course in and on your skin, teeth, guts, genitals, nasal cavities, etc. In fact, everywhere we have actually looked has bacteria, including healthy breast milk, amniotic fluid (probably), blood, semen, lungs, and more. Moreover, these microbiomes can have hundreds (as in human dentitia, milk, and vaginas) to thousands (as in mammalian guts) of different kinds of bacteria. You cannot survive in the real world without your bacteria. To give just one example, your bacteria produce essential amino acids that your body cannot synthesize or extract from what you eat. Other examples of our reliance on bacteria: they fix nitrogen for plants, digest grass for cattle and wood for termites, produce antibiotics, determine the sex of some insects, and more. Even cooler, in my opinion, is that we don’t know what most of these bacteria are, how they live, or what they do. We only know they are there. This means that every time we look, we are very likely to discover (many) new “species” of bacteria. It is as if every time we examine a tablespoon of dirt, a wall swab, or a breath of air, we make a major new discovery, far surpassing Darwin’s experiences on the Beagle.Yet we can only grow about 3% (estimated) of the bacteria we find. So, how do we know they are there? We take all the DNA in a sample (a skin swab, a bit of poop, some dirt, whatever), chop it up, sequence it, and put the sequences back together. This is new. Only in the last 15 years or so have we been able to sequence unknown DNA on very large scales. It used to be necessary to already know what part of a DNA molecule looked like, in order to design so-called “primers” to jump start the sequencing process. Moreover, we used to need to grow bacteria before we could get enough DNA to sequence. In both cases, this presumed we already knew quite a bit about what bacteria were present, so that discovery was very limited. Also, until recently, computers were not powerful enough to handle huge volumes of data, or to figure out which DNA fragments belonged together. Not so long ago, the accepted wisdom was that bacteria (and viruses, and microscopic fungi) were mostly bad, either giving us diseases, damaging our crops, or infecting our livestock. The assumption was that “bacteria” and “pathogen” were nearly synonymous. After all, we call our current theory of disease “the germ theory”. I remember once giving a talk about microbiomes at a public event in the Moscow Alehouse while people were enjoying their beer and burgers. Afterwards, a clearly upset patron approached me, complaining that he didn’t want to hear about nasty bacteria, especially in his gut, while he was eating. I was astonished. Didn’t he realize that the ex-cow he was eating wouldn’t exist without bacteria or that he couldn’t digest it without his own gut bacteria, let alone that the alcohol in his beer was essentially yeast excrement? We need to stop thinking about the microscopic world as the enemy, and instead think of ourselves (and our crops, livestock, homes, etc.) as partners with them. Hence Yong’s subtitle, “a Grander View of Life.”That bacteria dominate the world really shouldn’t be a surprise. They far out number us. A patch of your intestine the size of your thumbnail has more bacteria than all humans that have ever existed. It shouldn’t be a surprise that they can do so many things or that they live in so many places. They were the only living things on Earth for two billion year, almost half of Earth’s existence. We shouldn’t be surprised that the human body has 100 times more bacterial than human genes. Humans have only for about one five hundredth of one percent of the time that bacteria have. I think it is unfortunate that Yong didn’t go with the shorter and, I think, more accurate and interesting title that he mentions in passing, namely “I Am Multitudes.” This is a bacterial planet.Full disclosure: when I have on my scientist hat, this is what I do for a living. I study cool microbiomes, such as the skin microbiome of a highly toxic newt, the microbiome in breast milk, the microbiome of mud from the bottom of the ocean, the human vaginal microbiome, and the microbiome in the gut of premature infants with cystic fibrosis. As a computer scientist, most of what I do is develop new algorithms interpret DNA data, but I also sometimes work directly with the biology. I chose to do microbiome science because it is so very cool to be part of a scientific revolution, and because the people, such as those profiled in this book, are fascinating.I have intentionally not given any details about which microbiomes Yong discusses, nor what they do in their environments. I don’t want to spoil the discoveries for you. Suffice it to say that I Contain Multitudes captures the excitement and scope of this field. Read it. You will be infected, intellectually!

Famously, according to Douglas Adams, The Hitchiker's Guide to the Galaxy (not the novel, the 'actual' guide) begin by telling you at length how big space is, but then 'After a while the style settles down a bit and it starts telling you things you actually need to know' - and the opening of Ed Yong's exploration of the microbiome, the complex world of bacterial life inside us and generally in living things and around the world, is rather reminiscent of this. In the first couple of chapters, we are fed fact after fact in a staccato collection of information that has no sense of narrative or flow, rather like a set of frenzied bullet points, which becomes wearing for the reader. For example there are two paragraphs in a row, one with practically all the sentences starting 'They', and the next with almost all beginning 'We'll'. Thankfully, though, like the HHGTTG, We Are Multitude then settles down and gets on with job in hand.It's a job that Ed Yong does very well. It's hardly news that we have many, many bacterial cells in us (though it does biologists no scientific favours when we discover the much used 'ten times as many as human cells' figure was just picked out of the air and has no scientific basis). However, Yong quickly takes us beyond that to explore the nuances of a very intricate relationship between bacteria and more complex life that could be summarised as 'Can't live with them, can't live without them.' Even many of our most hated bacterial foes can have positive roles at the right place and the right time.What certainly comes across is that our knee-jerk reaction of 'germs are bad' leads to an overemphasis on removing them, where actually they are often doing a useful job. When we go mad with our antibacterial cleansers, we are more like to wipe out good bacteria, leaving space for colonisation by nasties, than we are to simply kill off a threat. And Yong gives us a dramatic tour of the sheer variety of microbes and the environments in which different bacterial life can thrive, whether we talking black smokers or dolphin armpits.Every now and then, we get some excellent storytelling, but the use of example after example does give the impression to the non-biologist of the kind of approach that led Rutherford to comment that all science is either physics or stamp collecting - there is a fair amount of stamp collecting here. However, whenever the reader is beginning to feel that they are losing interest, up comes a really interesting part. I loved, for example, the story of the way that bacteria actually re-engineer the physical structure of a glow-in-the-dark squid. And it's hard not be impressed by the description of bacteria surveys being undertaken in a brand new hospital as it is brought into use, to see where the bugs come from. One of the particularly engaging observations is the emphasis on the benefits of open windows to allow bacteria to come in from the outside. Your mum's enthusiasm for getting you out in the fresh air was justified after all.If there's one message the reader comes away with, it's that we need to be more nuanced in our thinking about bacteria - sometimes, it seems almost to be a case of 'sit back and enjoy the ride, because whatever you do will probably mess things up.' You'll never look at a probiotic yogurt drink or a bottle of toilet cleaner the same again.

A fantastic book covering an area that is the hot topic of the day in biology: the microbiome and how it affects us all. However, as the author shows, there is currently a lot of hype surrounding some aspects of the microbiome, like in probiotics and fecal transplants. This book will help readers to navigate the minefield of papers and articles about the microbiome and show you just what we know and, more importantly, what we still don't know about it and how it can affect our lives and the environment.Ed Yong starts with a look at how people like Leeuwenhoek discovered the world of bacteria and then goes on to show how microbes can interact with multi-celled organisms, like us, to form and grow them; for the fact is the genes and cells of animals (and probably plants) need the microbes to help mediate the growth of bodies. Experiments with sterile (germ-free) animals show they don't grow or develop well without the microbes.However, the microbes are not the selfless helpers of animals. Like any other organism, they also act in their self-interest and will grow and multiply uncontrollably inside animals (causing diseases) unless they are controlled by the body. This back-and-forth of conflict and cooperation is shown to occur not just in bodies but also in our environment. Numerous examples, from coral reefs that grow or die depending on which types of microbes are around, to malnutrition in children, are evidence of the action of different kinds of microbiomes.Now that we are starting to learn about microbiomes, what can we do about it. Here, the author covers the various experiments and studies that have been conducted or are being conducted to try to understand how various microbiomes work. He is also careful not to over-state the results of the studies for, in reality, we still know very little about the interactions of the microbes in the microbiomes and the changes we introduce may be for the better or worse.This book covers the very latest research into the microbiome; a look at the very long list of endnotes show some research where the results have yet to be published at the book's release. A definite must-read for those who want a glimpse of how microbes, despite their very small size, can affect our environment in surprising ways.

Ed Yong may just be the best science writer currently working. In either case, this regular contributor to The Atlantic has written a brilliant book about the teeming microbial communities that live inside us, governing our health, illness, allergies and relationships with others.People who know about this topic generally have heard about it in terms of the somewhat offputting idea of fecal transplants, in which people with persistent C. difficile gut infections have been cured by giving them a sample of someone else's stool. It is a mark of how broad and incisive this book is that Yong doesn't get to the fecal transplant topic until the penultimate chapter.The rest of the book ranges far and wide through nature, from the scientist studying the microbiomes of zoo animals to the ones studying light emitting squids to those that are cataloging how microbial communities grow inside buildings ranging from hospitals to hotel rooms.Yong explains with literate craft how we have been hampered by a simplistic two-sided view of this hugely diverse microbial world. We either think of microbes as disease causing baddies that need to be vanquished, or as benign "probiotic" species that will turn us into healthy Birkenstock-wearing granola-crunching citizens. In fact, these microbial communities live in a tenuous and shifting balance with their hosts, whether they are mosquitoes, beewolf wasps or human beings, and if we aren't careful, tampering with these communities can cause more harm than good.Nevertheless, there are many exciting possibilities being explored by researchers for making our lives better, from breeding mosquitoes than are incapable of carrying the dengue or Zika viruses, to 3D-printed balls that will seed our hospital rooms with healthy microbes to specially designed microbial pills that can be dispensed to deal with an individual's particular ailment.We truly do contain multitudes, and this is one of the best, most gracefully written and cutting edge science books I've encountered.

All of us have an abundant microscopic menagerie, collectively known as the microbiota or microbiome. They live on our surface, inside our bodies, and sometimes inside our very cells. the vast majority of them are bacteria, but there are also other tiny organisms including fungi (such as yeasts) and archaea... There are viruses too, in unfathomable numbers...I've read some books recently about the microbiome. The Hidden Half of Nature: The Microbial Roots of Life and Health touched on it, but not satisfyingly enough. Missing Microbes: How the Overuse of Antibiotics Is Fueling Our Modern Plagues was really great, although almost a bit too evangelistic in his fervor for our resident bacteria and his ideas of how our mistreatment of it might be driving modern diseases. Ed Yong does a great job of toning that down a little and explaining how scientists believe our bodies became so dependent upon them for our health.Unfortunately, much of the book doesn't really talk about the human microbiome at all. He talks about pangolins and squid and aphids and termites and mealy bugs and... you get the (sometimes tedious) point. For me the strongest parts were where he discussed how our microbiome helps us to digest foods or how it protects us from sickness. Some points I got from the book were that human health is best with 1) natural childbirth, 2) breast-feeding, and 3) having pets in the home, especially dogs. And I absolutely loved his sense of humor - a little on the dry side, but right up my alley. So, while I was hoping for more emphasis on human health, it was still a very interesting book.

For most of human history, microbes were invisible to us, though we sometimes saw their effects. After they were discovered, we paid most attention to the bacteria that caused disease or the bacteria that could fight disease.In recent decades, our attitude has shifted from fighting bacteria at every step, to understanding its vital role in the health of all living species. With the new view of bacteria, and our greater ability to understand it, we've begun to use it in ever subtler ways to improve the health of ourselves and other species.If you want a shorter read, try reading the first few chapters, which outline the history of our understanding of bacteria and will give you an idea of how amazing it is. Then, read the last two chapters: Microbes à la Carte and Tomorrow the World.The last two might be the most important, because almost all popular journalism about bacteria comes with all these promises of how bacteria will cure weight gain, how a new superbug is going to wipe out the entire human species, or how eating yogurt, kombucha, and sauerkraut is going to give you the bowel movements you've always dreamed of. At least, that's always my interpretation of these articles. The last portion of the book sheds more light on these ideas, and thereby tempers them. It's not that bacteria isn't dynamic cellular life in its rawest form that can do pretty much anything. It is and it can. But life is very complex and often does not have simple solutions.

There is a mind-boggling amount of information in this book. I am glad it was my first book delving into the microbes and how they interact with life because it doesn't just focus on humans and our digestive tract. It does touch on it, but it covers so much more. How microbes interact in nature and with other animals, how our hospitals may actually be too clean and causing us harm, how probiotics you can buy may not be what you think they are (they are overly hyped), how microbes work in teams at times, how too much of a good thing is actually a bad thing. This book is great for an overview of the interactions of microbes with nature in general. It goes into a bit more detail on some of the subjects I mentioned above. I look forward to finding out more about the interactions in humans.

Outstanding popular science book by of of the best in the business. Engaging, enlightening, elegantly written. The book takes us on a tour of the rapidly growing field of microbiology, demonstrating their crucial importance to species (including humans) and entire ecologies. Useful when thinking about the world and practically useful in living your life, not many science book can pull both off. Several themes I have came across before in the press or science blogs, even these capture the interest due to the quality of the writing. Bringing to life even the gross parts about fecal transplants (featuring an unfortunate blender!).Only minor quibble would be that even at a few years old large stride have already taken place that will of course not be present, that is most clear in the final chapter which feels a little threadbare compared to all of the others.

I follow the author's "Not Exactly Rocket Science" blog, so I was already an admirer of his clear explanations and dry witted prose about various scientific ideas. This book did not disappoint. I have been reading more and more in short news articles about the microbiome - the trillions of microbes that live within us. But this book gave the author the chance to explore the microbes of the world - from the deepest ocean, insects and animals, plant life and humans of course - and see how the multitudes of microbes at various times protect, destroy, change, adapt and interact with various hosts. It was fascinating to read about and I will look forward to finding out about new discoveries in this field.

Fascinating insights--it won't be fire or ice that will take us down, it will be bacteria! They were here long before we were and will most certainly outlive us. That's actually not what he's saying at all, but sort of the message I took away from it. This is a super accessible science book. I thought some of it was too niche or not interesting, but none of it was too difficult to understand. I also like his carefulness in examining the crazy claims of the "probiotics" evangelists. The book made me feel really lucky that I was able to birth my babies naturally and breastfeed them for a year each. Human milk is remarkable!

Biologically speaking, this book was quite fascinating. The research accumulated was presented well and explained for all to understand. Many different studies were mentioned but it didn't have a dull feel. I liked the bits about the mosquitoes and frogs. Microbes are opening up new avenues to deal with old problems ...... without chemicals. Who knew microbes would make for a great read.It is interesting to speculate the power of the microbe and how it can make the difference between sickness and health, death and life.

Fascinating subject. Great anecdotes framed by a biographical sketch: meet a scientist, hear how they had a question and pursued the answer, etc. Wonderful descriptions of the lifecycle of different microbes, their impact on host organisms, and author's speculation on how the symbiosis began.But the author repeats this template over and over again. A magazine story repeated twenty times. All these wonderful details remained details.

This is a science book, possibly the most definitive book about bacteria and other microbes. Sounds yucky and dry, doesn't it? Well, no, because Yong injects some humor into the narrative and keeps the pace snappy and fun. There is a lot of fascinating information here, much of it gut-churning, but I enjoyed the smart, cheeky ride.

The fact a book about microorganisms is a page-turner is a testament to this author's skill. Plus, you don't have to be a biologist to understand or appreciate it. It's wonderfully written, impressively researched, and hugely fascinating. Well, at least it was to me.

I sincerely want to enjoy this book. To finish it and gush about what I have learned, recommend it to my loved ones, and hear similarly great reviews. Buckle up. This is not that review. I did not enjoy this book. In fact, there were several moments that this felt like a punishment. Many of the chapters felt convoluted and meandering. I gained some fun parcels of knowledge. I can better appreciate how the microbiotic world impacts all of evolution. Amazing. Thinking about medicine as gardening instead of warfare? Meaningful. But, these bits of knowledge do not outweigh the book overall.

I fascinating book all about the microbes all around us and other creatures. I learned a lot in the process of reading this including how much we don't know about our microbiome. For instance, probiotic yoghurts don't work, well they don't repopulate our gut flora anyway, but scientists are successfully eliminating dengue fever by introducing a specific bacteria to the mosquitos.

A fascinating exploration of the complex invisible ecosystems that inhabit our physical bodies. Each of our bodies contains more microbial cells, which are genetically not us or even human, than cells which contain our own DNA. How these primitive life forms interact with us and with other microbes determines more about our well being than we have ever previously imagined.A lot of this book was a little more detailed and scientific than I cared for. But overall I found the topic extremely interesting, and I now feel a little more informed about a whole new area of research and discovery and scientific breakthroughs that certainly awaits us.

It can be a real sucker punch to your sense of self-identity when you realize that every cell in your body is matched by at least one microbe. As an individual, you are not measured just by your mettle but by the mettle of your microbiome⁠—all the microbes collectively on and in your person. I Contain Multitudes boldly brings to your attention just how teeming the world and we are with invisible life.As some of the earliest forms of life on Earth, bacteria have developed diverse mechanisms and processes to survive on land, sea, and the most extreme environments. In the words of Yong, bacteria are "metabolic wizards," now my new favorite way of describing how they can break down most anything: crude oil, plastics, plant material, you name it. In essence, if there's a way, you can bet there's a bacteria that has found it. Ed Yong's goal here is to dispel the overwhelming notion that bacteria are an evil to be eradicated, the infamous pathogens responsible for tuberculosis, cholera, tetanus, and the plague. Those bacteria are only a tiny drop in the bucket; there's a planet full of fascinating microbes that are harmless or, taking it a step further, essential for animal survival.The numerous examples which Yong provides of important symbiotic, or mutually beneficial, relationships between animal and bacteria demonstrate that such mutual coevolution simply cannot be ignored. Insects, squids, and yes, humans would find their immune defense and nutritional health wanting should the little microbes disappear. Mention about the scary Clostridium difficile, a bacteria that ravages the human gut when antibiotics clean out the healthy microbes within, hits close to home about the importance of recognizing the microbiome as a community, a vibrant ecosystem. There has only been a recent paradigm shift in recognizing both scientifically and medically that bacteria aren't solely organisms which ought to be nuked out of existence. On the flip side, that can lead to some overzealous claims about their benevolence (sorry, natural selection is still cranking away), but Yong is careful to point out when the data behind wild claims about bacterial miracles is just a little too shaky to trust. There's a lack of quantification for much of what Yong says, but I blame the state of the research field more than his skills as a science writer for a popular audience. He qualifies and admits the inherent weaknesses that a number of studies about the microbiome have; frankly, there is plenty of bad science out there. Instead, Yong chooses to look optimistically, to pique our attention towards the great potential for research results that are yet to be released. Though the information can become a little dense at times, Yong delivers a wide berth of information with easily digestible and dynamic language. At times, he writes with almost a childlike wonder at the biology, passionate about new discoveries and the future directions of research. Microbes are an undeniable part of each of us, and though Yong doesn't go full force towards heavy hitting questions about who we are, there is plenty of relevance to our lives and our worldview stocked in this book. Ultimately, I Contain Multitudes leaves us readers with our hopes raised for some incredible scientific advancements to be made with the proper lens—a lens zoomed into the microbes, that is.

"Do I contradict myself? Very well, then I contradict myself, I am large, I contain multitudes." - Walt WhitmanI'm a priori inclined to like bacteria. My favorite is Oenococcus Oeni, even though that's not the only bacteria that causes the poorly-named malolactic fermentation during winemaking (malolactic conversion is better jargon, but I digress). No one really extols the virtues of super young red wine (I mean, besides those marketing masters in Beaujolais, but I'm firmly of the opinion that, if the terroir's worth tastin', skip the carbonic maceration). Straight out of the fermentation tank, red wine tastes like tart apples, which is not generally what you want. Introduce a little Oenococcus Oeni, and the apple taste softens up into butter. And I don't trust people who don't like butter.Northern California is apparently swarming with hippies, such as myself, who imagine that we're all interconnected cosmic beings embracing within a universal stew (or maybe cheese plate, we do a lot of wine and cheese up here, and I've been driving through redwoods for a few hours so it's a little hard for me to come up with a fitting metaphor). I Contain Multitudes is not only poetically written, but it deepens the feeling that we're all in this together. It's kind of like that episode of The Magic School Bus where the gang shrinks to the size of a blood cell and floats around the human body, but for educated grown ups who also listen to NPR. I recommend I Contain Multitudes, especially for people who want a more nuanced explanation of the hygiene hypothesis, fecal transplants, probiotics, and other bacteria-related stuff being reported in the news these days. Also recommended for stoners who want to think about the fact that we live in cities, but we also contain cities of bacteria, and the bacteria are floating in our bodies, and we're all fucking floating in space.

“I Contain Multitudes,” is the first book by one of my favorite science journalists, Ed Yong. The focus of the book is microbiomes – the microbial ecosystems that exist on and in nearly every object on our planet (including us). Yong initially explores how scientific perceptions of the microbial world have changed from the first studies by Leeuwenhoek to the golden age of antibiotics to our microbiome-paper-a-day modern era and then jumps into ongoing microbiome research. The book is rich in excerpts from interviews with many leading scientists and covers a range of topics from the human microbiome to ecological consequences of altering microbial communities. As with Yong’s writing elsewhere, it is exciting and engaging while remaining rigorously factual and avoiding sensationalism. My one criticism is that the book lacked a strong over-arching narrative – it felt like I was jumping from one fascinating story to the next without a clear sense of direction. I would highly recommend the book to anyone interested in gaining a more nuanced understanding of the microbial world.

Most of us have heard about the human microbiome now, and are aware that we have more microbes in and on our bodies than we have cells, but that's just the beginning. Ed Yong has captured a superb snapshot of a rapidly developing field. Microbes are not good or bad, as we used to be taught. They just are. Every animal, including us of course, is a dynamic ecosystem balancing countless species of bacteria plus viruses and other icky things. Microbes have evolved along with each other and animals in a balance that usually works best for everyone, because they were naturally selected to do so.Ed Yong writes so beautifully and naturally that you can gallop through this book with joy. His sly witticisms, stories, and elegant prose make a very complex subject understandable and consistently fascinating. And how refreshing it is to hear him say wee, poo, and squirting from its backside instead of pretending to be grown up with scientific Latinisms.

This is a beautiful book. It was easy to see that he has a passion for the subject. His writing, at times, could be described as poetic. I can't pretend that I understood or will remember the majority of what he said but, it wasn't really that kind of book. This is a book that is meant to inspire the reader with a greater sense of wonder at the beauty and complexity of both our own bodies and of the world around us.I may just have to take a microbiology class at my local Jr College to gain a better understanding of the material this book covered.

Most of this book was really interesting, with some pockets of 'deep knowledge' that I wasn't that intrigued about and lost me, but otherwise read up on microbes! #bookstagram #bookworm #icontainmultitudes

This book not only opened my eyes to the ubiquitous and brilliant nature of microbes, it gave me a newfound appreciation for the ones who cohabit my body – millions and millions of tiny little creatures that have turned me into a living, dynamic ecosystem. While having a basic understanding of microbiology did help make it easier to understand the information in this book, the language has been made accessible even to audiences without any scientific background. Ed Young has a true gift for writing – his strength lies in his ability to fashion clever, easily-comprehensible analogies in order to break down complex biological systems and theories. Microbes are a cultural novelty. We've only had a couple centuries to learn how to think about them, and all the metaphors we've developed in that time are based on some thin gropings in a world much older and more complex than we've realized until very recently. So part of Yong's goal is to introduce some of the research that brings us into that new world, and another part is to confront some of those metaphors and show how inadequate they are in light of that new evidence. There's not much of a thesis or a structure here; Yong is a great science writer and has covered a lot of research in articles, and this book feels like a series of those articles strung together around loosely related themes. A lot of that research is really amazing. I thought I was pretty hip to the microbiome stuff and had a sense of how important microbial ecology was. But there were still lots of revelations left for me here. The fundamental role of microbes in shaping animal development, for instance, or the enormous spectrum of what Wolbachia does in insect biology. There are two big ideas running through all of these stories. One is the extended phenotype: the idea that organisms inherit genes that code for their own bodies but also for compounds that shape the environment of other organisms. While Yong lets scientists waffle over the precise utility of the term "hologenome" for the genes of an organism and its symbionts (since the jobs must be done but often the organisms that do them can vary tremendously). But there are dozens of stories of particular organisms outsourcing development and maintenance work to their symbionts, and eventually even acquiring them as part of their own genome. The line between symbiont and host is blurred in a dozen different ways.The other idea, which is somewhat more profound if more obvious and intuitive in retrospect, is that microbial ecology isn't magic. It's subject to the same concepts we use to describe other ecological systems, if with some major differences in the particulars. I've had this vague notion that microbes are sort of everywhere, all the time, and that they can always find substrates as soon as they exist, that they can form dormant bodies that can tolerate extended periods without resources, etc. This seems to be an exaggeration; ultimately, microbial ecology functions just like plant ecology or insect ecology: the community present is determined by available propagules and environmental niches (available resources, competitors, temperature and pH, etc). This is where Yong's book left me wanting more. There are enough examples that this picture starts to become clear, but I'm wanting a more explicit statement of how these things work in the aggregate. Because the example systems he covers make it quite clear that microbial communities occupy, to a greater or lesser extent, pretty much every surface and volume we ever interact with. And we still seem to only have the faintest idea what any of that actually means--what they do, how they're determined, etc. Part of the problem here is that, again, while it may be feasible to take samples and use genetic analysis to characterize what's present, that doesn't really mean anything to us. It's easy for us to think in terms of animal metaphors, or landscapes, to grasp the impact of an invasive plant or the extinction of a major predator. We can visualize it, and all the players have some kind of innate personality. Even things that have names and a known role may simply do something completely different in another place. Maybe that work has been done (Wolbachia, for instance, seems to have a fairly wide knowledge base). But in the context of this book, there are some odd juxtapositions. Yong will talk about how important it is for us to have the right communities of gut microbiota, and how an organism isn't a pathogen or a mutualist except under the right circumstances. But then in other places he'll describe particular microbes as opportunistic and weedy species that thrive in over-cleaned environments and how this state is dysbiotic and unhealthy. I guess I'm just wanting to know more about particular pathogenic species now, which are presumably especially well-studied?

Read this book if you are a doctor, nurse or public health official. Read this if you are an architect or botanist. Read this if you are very scared of germs and desire a sterile environment everywhere. This ground breaking book introduced to readers the world of microbiome, or world of microbes living inside other organisms. So there are bacteria everywhere on the surface and inside the gut of animals. They serve many critical functions: providing fluorescence for squids for camouflaging them from creatures below them. They live in termites’ stomach and digest wood fibres. They help kill pathogenic viruses and bacteria so protect the host. Breast milk provides food for benign gut bacteria such as Bacteroides fragilis that protects us from diarrhoea. They secrete mucus lining our gut that enables virus (bacteriophages) that kills harmful bacteria! They co-evolve with their hosts. This symbiosis is not always benign, but is based on mutual advantage. Some animals hosts certain bacteria in the larval stage but discard them once they grow up to be adults. Even our own gut microbiome changes with time, sometimes within days. Animals growing up in a sterile environment behave strangely and are prone to funny diseases. Babies acquire their first microbiome in the mothers’ birth canal and thus normal birth is still better than caesarean section. Rampant antibiotic use destroys our diverse microbiome, allowing bad bugs to overgrow. Probiotics help but they cannot stay long in our gut. Animals routinely eat each other’s stools to acquire its microbiome. Some clostridium difficile bacteria are so resistant that no antibiotics can kill them. Fecal transplant (yes transfer of stools) have been used successfully to cure patients of clostridium infection and has been approved by FDA. Unfortunately the effects on other illnesses such as inflammatory bowel syndrome and autism has not been consistent so far. Furthermore, some do-it-yourself cases have ended in severe infection of the recipient. Another use of our new knowledge is in medicine. Filariasis is a sickness that causes very swollen feet and legs because of roundworm infection. When they are killed, Wolbachia bacteria inside is released, triggering inflammation and destruction of lymph nodes. So the legs get permanently swollen. Now doxycycline is used to kill the Wolbachia first, then the roundworms can be killed easily without problems. An exciting new use is the discovery that Wolbachia also renders the Aedes mosquitos less able to carry the horrible dengue, Zika and Chikungunya viruses. So Aedes mosquitos infected with Wolbachia have been released to the wild to displace the wild type mosquitos (because infected females preferentially mate with infected males) and dengue has been controlled. This was started in Australia called the World Mosquito Program, and is being carried out in countries such as Indonesia and Mexico. Counterintuitively, toilets that are more often scrubbed have more easily colonised by E. coli (stool bacteria that transmit gastroenteritis). A diverse microbiome allows other less vicious germs to proliferate and compete with E. coli. Hospitals are too clean thus allowing antibiotic resistant bugs to proliferate, causing nosocomial infections. Florence Nightingale had it right: opening hospital windows decrease those infections by allowing entry of a more diverse microbiome through those windows!A solid 5 star book!

Absolutely loved this one!I've been interested in microbiome research for some time now, and finally decided to pick-up a book about it. This was the perfect one!As a side note, the last year or so I've been crafting a "microbiome diet" for myself (originally, I thought of it more as an "anti-inflammatory diet," with a high focus on anti-oxidants and various phytonutrients; meaning, lots of spices, and colorful fruits and vegetables). The main focus is to eat more plants, more variety of fiber (insoluble, soluble, resistant starch, inulin/prebiotics, etc), as well as common, traditional, probiotic foods (yogurt, kefir, sauerkraut, miso, kimchi, "raw" pickles, kombucha, etc). and even - counter-intuitively - some anti-bacterial foods (honey, hot peppers, grape seed extract, cinnamon, etc). I had heard of so many good correlations with having a healthy gut microbiome (reduced rates of cancer, heart disease, Alzheimer's, diabetes, etc - as well as improved mood, mental health and possibly even IQ!), that I wanted to do something to support mine. But, the science is still pretty new, so I didn't want to do anything drastic. Eating "healthier" seemed like the most effective, least drastic thing I could do. Then I dropped 10 lbs and a pants size, which was totally unintentional, but I won't complain. Now I tell people that I accidentally discovered the secret to weight loss: Get your daily recommended serving of fiber! (For women, this is 25g, for men 30-37g).My recommended list of high fiber foods includes:Overnight Oats (Cocoa-PB, often with a banana)Chia Pudding (often with berries)Cocoa-Banana-Peanut Butter smoothieRoasted Chickpeas (simple seasoning: garlic/salt/cayenne)Pumpkin Seeds (in-shell)Okra Chips (Sprouts carries them)Edamame PastaGuacamoleWhole Grain BreadDark ChocolateFig Cake (Whole Foods sometimes carries this)Dark Chocolate Covered Figs (Safeway has them)Peetos (pea-based cheetos)Harvest Snaps (lentil-based puffs, Tomato Basil flavor)Avocado Sandwich (Avocado, sauerkraut, mustard, hot banana pepper rings, and smoked gouda toasted on whole grain bread)Apple Slices with Peanut ButterArtichokes (Google "Magic Artichoke Dip")AsparagusMushroomsLentils (TasyBite brand is good, and convenient)Meatless Crumbles (I like the Quorn brand, derived from mycelium)Nut Bars (Costco's Kirkland brand has 7g of fiber per bar, and is tasty)

Every interaction leaves one permanently altered, or, to put it another way, your biome is never the same biome that it was before. Working at a public library I handle dozens of book everyday, all of which were handled by a wide variety of peoples, and what this experience does is that it forces me to encounter ideas, perspectives, and reading habits I never would have experienced on my own. It also allows me to encounter a wide variety of microscopic organisms.Ed Yong's book is one of those beautiful love letters to science in which a writer is able to communicate their passion for the field of science. Not only this, Song is able to infect me with his passion by teaching me about the kinds of microbes that infect me on a regular basis. I Contain Multitudes is infectious though, because the passion is on every page, and by the end of this book I was spellbound by how multifaceted the study of microbiomes and microbes actually was. Like many people I thought of microbes as just germs, little organisms that existed solely to make me sick. In this book Yong got me to reconsider this position. Not only that, but Long got me to reconsider my own biology and realize that the little bugs were not just alien organisms living inside of me or on me, they were, in essence, part of me. Yong observes how an individual's microbes evolve in relation to their host, adapting or in some cases being adapted by said host. After a time it becomes clear to the reader that their microbes are not just alien organisms, but part of a long evolutionary lineage that has allowed them to become the incredible species they are today, and even when Yong is writing about the symbiosis between microbes and aphids, mosquitos, and dogs the reader constantly bombarded by his passion and his ability to see the significance of these relationships.There's so many great reasons to read this book, I'm just going to settle on the fact that the man made fecal transplants something both fascinating to read about, and also something I actually wanted to learn more about.

This book takes a look at the world that is lurking behind everything that we see, touch, smell and feel. It's in the food we eat, the ground we walk on, the house we live in and inside our body, in the millions. The microbes that comprise this world are capable of causing diseases but also give us medicines, they cause decay but also keep the natural cycle in place and so much more. The book is the author's love letter to this microbial world, and much like what Siddharth Mukherjee did for Cancer in "Emperor of all Maladies", he charters the historical and ever evolving (literally) place that they occupy in our world.The book deals with everything that we need to know about the microbial world. From how they came into existence, to the role that have played in terra forming earth as we know it, to their importance in modern medicine, the author doesn't leave any stone unturned to showcase their importance. The book is very well researched and references numerous studies to back up it's claims. Yong is clearly super passionate about this stuff and in this he might seem to oversell the product, but he exercises restraint, bringing in a dose of a reality check as he remains quite optimistic about some of the tremendously far reaching applications that microbes can have on us and the society. It draws from a number of fields as the reach of the microbial world is quite far, from the depth of the ocean a mile or more below the surface, to the coldest and hottest regions knows to man, to the human gut, to the insides of a termite, we get a broad outlook on the amount of research that has goes into and still does into them.A really good book, which could have been edited a little better to keep the pace up, but still managed to keep you hooked. It's a must read for nature lovers, for those interested in science and who want to stay informed about the possibilities that the future holds for mankind.

This is my kind of science book: an approachable introduction to a previously confusing specialty, taking its title from Walt Whitman of all places. Ed Yong sees the poetry in microbiology, and shares that vision with his readers while explaining the history of our understanding of bacteria, the surprising ways bacteria interact with their environments and hosts, and the medical possibilities as we come to understand our own microbiomes. While my interest in Yong's topic lagged during the sections focusing mostly on insects, the sections about the environment and human interactions were most fascinating for me. I learned, among other things, that human babies do not have the microbes they need to be healthy until they pass through the birth canal and are breastfed; that certain bacteria have been shown to counteract or prevent inflammation of the sort associated with multiple sclerosis, at least in mice; that fecal transplants are a real thing that doctors prescribe to reset the gut bacteria of people with certain diseases; and most excitingly, that we could be heading towards a future where doctors prescribe us bacteria concoctions to alleviate medical problems, the way they today prescribe antibiotics. If any of this interests you, you should read I Contain Multitudes. It's not quite on the same level of awe as Emperor of All Maladies, but considering that I've been walking around happily envisioning the trillions of bacteria I interact with every day at work, at home, with my cat, and with my friends, I'd say this is a book that can certainly teach anyone something, and change the way you view our natural world.

This fascinating and informative book by the acclaimed British science writer Ed Yong explores the symbiotic relationships between microorganisms and more advanced life forms, including humans, and how these beneficial and sometimes harmful interactions affect our bodies' health and ability to function effectively, and the features that allow pathogenic species to colonize and infect us. Yong describes historical studies of these relationships, along with current research that could potentially transform how we treat infections such as elephantiasis, river blindness and Clostridium difficile colitis in humans and similar devastating ones in other species.

I very interesting and informative overview about symbiotic microbes. Yong has a gift for science writing, he neatly conveys complex information in a compulsively readable format. He also covers all types of symbiotic relationships from the very simple single-cell organisms and their one symbiotic bacteria to the human gut with its myriad microbial population. Recommended for everyone, particularly fans of David Quammen. (Aside: more pictures!! Why are there never enough pictures?) Also, many thanks to his US editors for not "Americanizing" Yong's British English.

Individuality is a cherished trait of sagacious beings. Man is the only such animal which is conscious of its self. Man stands alone in his mental transactions with the outside world. This aloofness is way off the true state of things. Very small microbes and other inanimate objects thrive in our body and are present in very large numbers on all our body parts. The presence of microbes is thought to be a bad thing in routine awareness sermons, but this is not necessarily so. Microbes are beneficial or neutral to us on most of the occasions and provide immense service to us. They keep our guts healthy, calibrate our immune systems, make us less sensitive to allergens and can even exert influence on our brains. This horde of microbes in our body makes each individual human being a multitude which acts in tandem to work as a symbiotic whole. Ed Yong is an award-winning science writer who regularly contributes to leading journals and scientific publications.The author makes a brilliant comparison scheme to present the contrast between life forms almost perennially lived on earth against others who are relatively latecomers to the party of life. He equates our planet’s entire life to a human year in which the present is just before midnight on December 31. On such a scale, the entry of humans was just half an hour ago, at 11.30 pm, while microbes ruled the globe between the months of March to October, that is, between their entry and the advent of higher organisms. This ingenuous example clarifies all doubts on the antiquity of microbes as compared to mammals or other higher forms of life.Microbes are everywhere, but due to the very small size of them, they remained invisible to mankind till the seventeenth century. It was then Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a pioneering lens-maker in Holland, witnessed these organisms everywhere – in water, in hand tools, in his body, home and everywhere! For a time, others couldn’t make lenses with the resolving power as Leeuwenhoek’s, but when at last they did, the scholars were shocked to find themselves colonized by these microbes. It took nearly another century to distinguish the good from the bad. Many microbes live in symbiosis with their hosts. It can also be said that microbes help us become what we are by modifying the genes of parent organisms in subtle ways. Biologists have experimentally demonstrated that organisms that live in sterile Lab-like environments where the microbes are strictly controlled suffer growth problems in the absence of friendly bacteria. Yong includes examples where the microbes affect the growth of brain. Specific strains of bacteria can be encouraged with the help of probiotics (the reverse process as antibiotics). Lack of exposure to symbiotic microbes had resulted in depression and anxiety in the hosts.The book argues that the sharp distinction between good and bad microbes is an oversimplification. Even the good ones create life-threatening situations when their position is changed, say from the gut to the blood stream. Mitochondria are present in every mammal cell, which generates the energy the cell so dearly needs. Scientists presume that mitochondria were independent microbes in the beginning of life and later settled inside the animal cell in a case of mutually beneficial symbiosis. Even with a history of living together for billions of years, if the mitochondrion is to enter the blood stream somehow, the immune system of the host attacks it with vigour as if it was a foreign particle and not a part of its own body. Yong presents the case of Helicobacter pylori, the bacterium in our gut that causes ulcer and stomach cancer. A very bad guy, obviously. But what will happen if we kill all of them in our guts? Scientists warn that we are in for more trouble, as these bacteria also protects against oesophageal cancer! As in life, it is a fine line that separates the good from the ugly in the case of microbes as well.The clever ways in which mothers help their babies grow microbes in their guts is interesting to read. The author has used many scientific terms to describe the process, but one such case is very noteworthy. Human breast milk contains a family of chemicals called Human Milk Oligosaccharides (HMO) which can’t be digested by the infant! Why on earth are such chemicals present in mother’s milk? The shocking answer is that these are good for a specific species of bacteria in the child’s long intestine. HMO nourishes these microbes, which in turn produces short-chain fatty acids. These feed the infant’s gut cells by making adhesive proteins that seal the gap between gut cells and anti-inflammatory molecules that calibrate the immune system. Needless to say, babies nurtured with bottled milk don’t develop this familiarity of the immune system to microbes. This results in inflammations where the immune system overreacts even to benign external particles. The book also speculates that microbes control obesity. Obese people have more Firmicutes and fewer Bacteroidetes than their leaner counterparts in their stomach. Transferring these microbes among lab mice showed that those mice which received microbes that characterized obesity put in more weight and vice versa. There is, however, no assurance that this result can be repeated in humans.Do you remember the scary day when New Scientist magazine trumpeted on its cover that Darwin was wrong? It talked about a system of gene transfer which is horizontal, that is, from one individual to another without any reproductive act called Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT). This differed with the vertical scheme Darwin had in mind, that is, from parent to offspring. The devil was in the details, and if you had read the whole article, it emphasized Darwin’s theorem rather than upsetting it. But for those who judge a book by its cover, it presented an avoidable opportunity to score on the supposed ‘error’ in Darwinism. HGT is widely seen in the world of microbes. Yong presents the curious case of the ‘nori’ seaweed that is a delicacy in Japan. Humans normally can’t digest the seaweed as the gut bacteria are unable to process them. But those who ate them first ingested marine bacteria skilled in the job. It exchanged genes with normal gut bacteria and entered its genome. Then it proceeded to colonize people via the normal biome transfer between parent and child.In the latter chapters of the book, the author describes about several revolutionary techniques of healing with bacteria, which are generally interesting but revolting at times. The faecal microbiota transplant (FMT) techniques may provide a fast cure for stomach-related issues, but it shows that a microbiologist’s career is not always glamorous! Manipulating the microbiome of an entire region or a person is discussed at length, but Yong tactfully stops short of anticipating repercussions that may arise when one plays with an entire biome. If the author is to be believed – and there are many solid reasons to do so – microbes are definitely going to play a significant part in formulating the therapies of the future. The book is neatly written and displays the confidence of the author in the beneficence of what he describes to mankind. A number of colour plates add to the visual appeal. A good number of Notes and a comprehensive index enhance the utility of the book.The book is highly recommended.
