This book is also brimming with humour and passion. I particularly enjoyed the section at the end regarding synthetic biology and the potential for “microbial medicine” in our future. It completely changed my perspective on microorganisms, and I can’t recommend it enough.
Reading about Biology and Microbes has never been this fun.
If you want to read an accurate book about microbes, this is the one. It’s rooted in science, not in speculation. I really appreciated this book!

Microbes are a cultural novelty. We've only had a couple centuries to learn how to think about them, and all the metaphors we've developed in that time are based on some thin gropings in a world much older and more complex than we've realized until very recently. So part of Yong's goal is to introduce some of the research that brings us into that new world, and another part is to confront some of those metaphors and show how inadequate they are in light of that new evidence. There's not much of a thesis or a structure here; Yong is a great science writer and has covered a lot of research in articles, and this book feels like a series of those articles strung together around loosely related themes. A lot of that research is really amazing. I thought I was pretty hip to the microbiome stuff and had a sense of how important microbial ecology was. But there were still lots of revelations left for me here. The fundamental role of microbes in shaping animal development, for instance, or the enormous spectrum of what Wolbachia does in insect biology. There are two big ideas running through all of these stories. One is the extended phenotype: the idea that organisms inherit genes that code for their own bodies but also for compounds that shape the environment of other organisms. While Yong lets scientists waffle over the precise utility of the term "hologenome" for the genes of an organism and its symbionts (since the jobs must be done but often the organisms that do them can vary tremendously). But there are dozens of stories of particular organisms outsourcing development and maintenance work to their symbionts, and eventually even acquiring them as part of their own genome. The line between symbiont and host is blurred in a dozen different ways.The other idea, which is somewhat more profound if more obvious and intuitive in retrospect, is that microbial ecology isn't magic. It's subject to the same concepts we use to describe other ecological systems, if with some major differences in the particulars. I've had this vague notion that microbes are sort of everywhere, all the time, and that they can always find substrates as soon as they exist, that they can form dormant bodies that can tolerate extended periods without resources, etc. This seems to be an exaggeration; ultimately, microbial ecology functions just like plant ecology or insect ecology: the community present is determined by available propagules and environmental niches (available resources, competitors, temperature and pH, etc). This is where Yong's book left me wanting more. There are enough examples that this picture starts to become clear, but I'm wanting a more explicit statement of how these things work in the aggregate. Because the example systems he covers make it quite clear that microbial communities occupy, to a greater or lesser extent, pretty much every surface and volume we ever interact with. And we still seem to only have the faintest idea what any of that actually means--what they do, how they're determined, etc. Part of the problem here is that, again, while it may be feasible to take samples and use genetic analysis to characterize what's present, that doesn't really mean anything to us. It's easy for us to think in terms of animal metaphors, or landscapes, to grasp the impact of an invasive plant or the extinction of a major predator. We can visualize it, and all the players have some kind of innate personality. Even things that have names and a known role may simply do something completely different in another place. Maybe that work has been done (Wolbachia, for instance, seems to have a fairly wide knowledge base). But in the context of this book, there are some odd juxtapositions. Yong will talk about how important it is for us to have the right communities of gut microbiota, and how an organism isn't a pathogen or a mutualist except under the right circumstances. But then in other places he'll describe particular microbes as opportunistic and weedy species that thrive in over-cleaned environments and how this state is dysbiotic and unhealthy. I guess I'm just wanting to know more about particular pathogenic species now, which are presumably especially well-studied?

Read this book if you are a doctor, nurse or public health official. Read this if you are an architect or botanist. Read this if you are very scared of germs and desire a sterile environment everywhere. This ground breaking book introduced to readers the world of microbiome, or world of microbes living inside other organisms. So there are bacteria everywhere on the surface and inside the gut of animals. They serve many critical functions: providing fluorescence for squids for camouflaging them from creatures below them. They live in termites’ stomach and digest wood fibres. They help kill pathogenic viruses and bacteria so protect the host. Breast milk provides food for benign gut bacteria such as Bacteroides fragilis that protects us from diarrhoea. They secrete mucus lining our gut that enables virus (bacteriophages) that kills harmful bacteria! They co-evolve with their hosts. This symbiosis is not always benign, but is based on mutual advantage. Some animals hosts certain bacteria in the larval stage but discard them once they grow up to be adults. Even our own gut microbiome changes with time, sometimes within days. Animals growing up in a sterile environment behave strangely and are prone to funny diseases. Babies acquire their first microbiome in the mothers’ birth canal and thus normal birth is still better than caesarean section. Rampant antibiotic use destroys our diverse microbiome, allowing bad bugs to overgrow. Probiotics help but they cannot stay long in our gut. Animals routinely eat each other’s stools to acquire its microbiome. Some clostridium difficile bacteria are so resistant that no antibiotics can kill them. Fecal transplant (yes transfer of stools) have been used successfully to cure patients of clostridium infection and has been approved by FDA. Unfortunately the effects on other illnesses such as inflammatory bowel syndrome and autism has not been consistent so far. Furthermore, some do-it-yourself cases have ended in severe infection of the recipient. Another use of our new knowledge is in medicine. Filariasis is a sickness that causes very swollen feet and legs because of roundworm infection. When they are killed, Wolbachia bacteria inside is released, triggering inflammation and destruction of lymph nodes. So the legs get permanently swollen. Now doxycycline is used to kill the Wolbachia first, then the roundworms can be killed easily without problems. An exciting new use is the discovery that Wolbachia also renders the Aedes mosquitos less able to carry the horrible dengue, Zika and Chikungunya viruses. So Aedes mosquitos infected with Wolbachia have been released to the wild to displace the wild type mosquitos (because infected females preferentially mate with infected males) and dengue has been controlled. This was started in Australia called the World Mosquito Program, and is being carried out in countries such as Indonesia and Mexico. Counterintuitively, toilets that are more often scrubbed have more easily colonised by E. coli (stool bacteria that transmit gastroenteritis). A diverse microbiome allows other less vicious germs to proliferate and compete with E. coli. Hospitals are too clean thus allowing antibiotic resistant bugs to proliferate, causing nosocomial infections. Florence Nightingale had it right: opening hospital windows decrease those infections by allowing entry of a more diverse microbiome through those windows!A solid 5 star book!

Absolutely loved this one!I've been interested in microbiome research for some time now, and finally decided to pick-up a book about it. This was the perfect one!As a side note, the last year or so I've been crafting a "microbiome diet" for myself (originally, I thought of it more as an "anti-inflammatory diet," with a high focus on anti-oxidants and various phytonutrients; meaning, lots of spices, and colorful fruits and vegetables). The main focus is to eat more plants, more variety of fiber (insoluble, soluble, resistant starch, inulin/prebiotics, etc), as well as common, traditional, probiotic foods (yogurt, kefir, sauerkraut, miso, kimchi, "raw" pickles, kombucha, etc). and even - counter-intuitively - some anti-bacterial foods (honey, hot peppers, grape seed extract, cinnamon, etc). I had heard of so many good correlations with having a healthy gut microbiome (reduced rates of cancer, heart disease, Alzheimer's, diabetes, etc - as well as improved mood, mental health and possibly even IQ!), that I wanted to do something to support mine. But, the science is still pretty new, so I didn't want to do anything drastic. Eating "healthier" seemed like the most effective, least drastic thing I could do. Then I dropped 10 lbs and a pants size, which was totally unintentional, but I won't complain. Now I tell people that I accidentally discovered the secret to weight loss: Get your daily recommended serving of fiber! (For women, this is 25g, for men 30-37g).My recommended list of high fiber foods includes:Overnight Oats (Cocoa-PB, often with a banana)Chia Pudding (often with berries)Cocoa-Banana-Peanut Butter smoothieRoasted Chickpeas (simple seasoning: garlic/salt/cayenne)Pumpkin Seeds (in-shell)Okra Chips (Sprouts carries them)Edamame PastaGuacamoleWhole Grain BreadDark ChocolateFig Cake (Whole Foods sometimes carries this)Dark Chocolate Covered Figs (Safeway has them)Peetos (pea-based cheetos)Harvest Snaps (lentil-based puffs, Tomato Basil flavor)Avocado Sandwich (Avocado, sauerkraut, mustard, hot banana pepper rings, and smoked gouda toasted on whole grain bread)Apple Slices with Peanut ButterArtichokes (Google "Magic Artichoke Dip")AsparagusMushroomsLentils (TasyBite brand is good, and convenient)Meatless Crumbles (I like the Quorn brand, derived from mycelium)Nut Bars (Costco's Kirkland brand has 7g of fiber per bar, and is tasty)

Example that made me boggle the most: frog-killing fungus epidemic is described as terrible for "frog lovers" rather than for terrible for frogs. Oh, many of the endnotes are well worth reading! Lots of little enlightening and entertaining tidbits mixed in with the drier stuff.

This is a very interesting book, but most of it is "interesting" in the sense of providing a laundry list of facts that make you go "hmm...neat!" I liked the book, but frankly it wasn't until the last three chapters that I found a narrative. Perhaps that is because I am less interested in a collection of facts about what we do and do not (more the latter than the former) about microbes, and more interested in how this translates into practical application. I wouldn't recommend listening to this one in audiobook. You will feel more like someone is reading you a list than someone is telling you about story, and thus I think it loses some of its wonder.

This fascinating and informative book by the acclaimed British science writer Ed Yong explores the symbiotic relationships between microorganisms and more advanced life forms, including humans, and how these beneficial and sometimes harmful interactions affect our bodies' health and ability to function effectively, and the features that allow pathogenic species to colonize and infect us. Yong describes historical studies of these relationships, along with current research that could potentially transform how we treat infections such as elephantiasis, river blindness and Clostridium difficile colitis in humans and similar devastating ones in other species.

I very interesting and informative overview about symbiotic microbes. Yong has a gift for science writing, he neatly conveys complex information in a compulsively readable format. He also covers all types of symbiotic relationships from the very simple single-cell organisms and their one symbiotic bacteria to the human gut with its myriad microbial population. Recommended for everyone, particularly fans of David Quammen. (Aside: more pictures!! Why are there never enough pictures?) Also, many thanks to his US editors for not "Americanizing" Yong's British English.

Excellent! Even though I was familiar with a lot of the material, Ed Yong's presentation kept me engaged. Like Mary Roach and Sam Kean, Yong has a gift for making science interesting and accessible for the layman. You'll learn about why grocery store probiotics are worthless, how microbes may help with autism, and what re-poopulation entails. Highly recommended in print or audiobook.

This book is an exhaustive look at microbes. It's fascinating! We hear a lot about microbiomes and such lately, but this book looks beyond human guts to explore how microbes shape the lives of animals, humans, buildings, plants, and ocean life. I learned a was thoroughly amazed many times while reading this book.

there were moments of awesomeness but also moments of detail bogging down the writing. Somewhat unavoidable in science writing but if The Emperor of All Maladies is the gold standard in the genre (of beautiful and clear description of complex concepts) this falls short. Still learning about the complex relationships between our microbes and us was super fascinating.

One of those books which could be condensed, quite effectively, into an excellent magazine article. Unfortunately, Yong decided against that and wrote this poorly organized volume that seems to state the same few facts many times over.
This is one of the best books I have read this year, maybe the best. Loved every minute of it.
7 -- so very interesting!
A beautifully written science book!!! Very interesting!!!

Individuality is a cherished trait of sagacious beings. Man is the only such animal which is conscious of its self. Man stands alone in his mental transactions with the outside world. This aloofness is way off the true state of things. Very small microbes and other inanimate objects thrive in our body and are present in very large numbers on all our body parts. The presence of microbes is thought to be a bad thing in routine awareness sermons, but this is not necessarily so. Microbes are beneficial or neutral to us on most of the occasions and provide immense service to us. They keep our guts healthy, calibrate our immune systems, make us less sensitive to allergens and can even exert influence on our brains. This horde of microbes in our body makes each individual human being a multitude which acts in tandem to work as a symbiotic whole. Ed Yong is an award-winning science writer who regularly contributes to leading journals and scientific publications.The author makes a brilliant comparison scheme to present the contrast between life forms almost perennially lived on earth against others who are relatively latecomers to the party of life. He equates our planet’s entire life to a human year in which the present is just before midnight on December 31. On such a scale, the entry of humans was just half an hour ago, at 11.30 pm, while microbes ruled the globe between the months of March to October, that is, between their entry and the advent of higher organisms. This ingenuous example clarifies all doubts on the antiquity of microbes as compared to mammals or other higher forms of life.Microbes are everywhere, but due to the very small size of them, they remained invisible to mankind till the seventeenth century. It was then Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a pioneering lens-maker in Holland, witnessed these organisms everywhere – in water, in hand tools, in his body, home and everywhere! For a time, others couldn’t make lenses with the resolving power as Leeuwenhoek’s, but when at last they did, the scholars were shocked to find themselves colonized by these microbes. It took nearly another century to distinguish the good from the bad. Many microbes live in symbiosis with their hosts. It can also be said that microbes help us become what we are by modifying the genes of parent organisms in subtle ways. Biologists have experimentally demonstrated that organisms that live in sterile Lab-like environments where the microbes are strictly controlled suffer growth problems in the absence of friendly bacteria. Yong includes examples where the microbes affect the growth of brain. Specific strains of bacteria can be encouraged with the help of probiotics (the reverse process as antibiotics). Lack of exposure to symbiotic microbes had resulted in depression and anxiety in the hosts.The book argues that the sharp distinction between good and bad microbes is an oversimplification. Even the good ones create life-threatening situations when their position is changed, say from the gut to the blood stream. Mitochondria are present in every mammal cell, which generates the energy the cell so dearly needs. Scientists presume that mitochondria were independent microbes in the beginning of life and later settled inside the animal cell in a case of mutually beneficial symbiosis. Even with a history of living together for billions of years, if the mitochondrion is to enter the blood stream somehow, the immune system of the host attacks it with vigour as if it was a foreign particle and not a part of its own body. Yong presents the case of Helicobacter pylori, the bacterium in our gut that causes ulcer and stomach cancer. A very bad guy, obviously. But what will happen if we kill all of them in our guts? Scientists warn that we are in for more trouble, as these bacteria also protects against oesophageal cancer! As in life, it is a fine line that separates the good from the ugly in the case of microbes as well.The clever ways in which mothers help their babies grow microbes in their guts is interesting to read. The author has used many scientific terms to describe the process, but one such case is very noteworthy. Human breast milk contains a family of chemicals called Human Milk Oligosaccharides (HMO) which can’t be digested by the infant! Why on earth are such chemicals present in mother’s milk? The shocking answer is that these are good for a specific species of bacteria in the child’s long intestine. HMO nourishes these microbes, which in turn produces short-chain fatty acids. These feed the infant’s gut cells by making adhesive proteins that seal the gap between gut cells and anti-inflammatory molecules that calibrate the immune system. Needless to say, babies nurtured with bottled milk don’t develop this familiarity of the immune system to microbes. This results in inflammations where the immune system overreacts even to benign external particles. The book also speculates that microbes control obesity. Obese people have more Firmicutes and fewer Bacteroidetes than their leaner counterparts in their stomach. Transferring these microbes among lab mice showed that those mice which received microbes that characterized obesity put in more weight and vice versa. There is, however, no assurance that this result can be repeated in humans.Do you remember the scary day when New Scientist magazine trumpeted on its cover that Darwin was wrong? It talked about a system of gene transfer which is horizontal, that is, from one individual to another without any reproductive act called Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT). This differed with the vertical scheme Darwin had in mind, that is, from parent to offspring. The devil was in the details, and if you had read the whole article, it emphasized Darwin’s theorem rather than upsetting it. But for those who judge a book by its cover, it presented an avoidable opportunity to score on the supposed ‘error’ in Darwinism. HGT is widely seen in the world of microbes. Yong presents the curious case of the ‘nori’ seaweed that is a delicacy in Japan. Humans normally can’t digest the seaweed as the gut bacteria are unable to process them. But those who ate them first ingested marine bacteria skilled in the job. It exchanged genes with normal gut bacteria and entered its genome. Then it proceeded to colonize people via the normal biome transfer between parent and child.In the latter chapters of the book, the author describes about several revolutionary techniques of healing with bacteria, which are generally interesting but revolting at times. The faecal microbiota transplant (FMT) techniques may provide a fast cure for stomach-related issues, but it shows that a microbiologist’s career is not always glamorous! Manipulating the microbiome of an entire region or a person is discussed at length, but Yong tactfully stops short of anticipating repercussions that may arise when one plays with an entire biome. If the author is to be believed – and there are many solid reasons to do so – microbes are definitely going to play a significant part in formulating the therapies of the future. The book is neatly written and displays the confidence of the author in the beneficence of what he describes to mankind. A number of colour plates add to the visual appeal. A good number of Notes and a comprehensive index enhance the utility of the book.The book is highly recommended.

I did not expect to like this book very much. After reading the hype and the blurb I expected a dumbed down account of how microbes influence every aspect of our lives and all the ways we can control them. I knew that research in this area was very fresh, and that conclusions in this field are pretty hard to come by, so I was afraid of reading a distorted picture of the science for the sake of sensationalism.And, in fact, the book had that exact optimistic tone that I was dreading. Something along the lines of: “Scientists hope that in 5 years they can use bacteria to disintegrate plastic and clean the oceans!” But the content is not the one-size-fits-all dollop of one extraordinary fact after another. As with other good books of scientific journalism, the content is a stream of experimental results and hypotheses, some more likely than others, and labeled as such. Yes, you could have bacteria eating plastic out of the oceans, but not yet. Yes, microbes do influence a great part of our development, because apparently the microbiome is the environmental element responsible for activating certain genes and also training the immune system (bye bye germs, hello allergies). But we are still trying to understand what elements are causing this and if any intervention on our part does more good than bad.And with a sexy title like this, it’s bound to be eye-catching. I’ve seen it compared to The Selfish Gene and The Botany of Desire: A Plant's-Eye View of the World on the publisher’s website. While, to my mind, Dawkins’ book is something which one could rightly compare only to a select few books, like “The Origin of Species”, Pollan’s book of scientific journalism is an apt comparison. Highly recommended reading material.

A Review of the AudiobookPublished by HarperAudio in 2016.Read by Charlie Anson.Duration: 9 hours, 52 minutes.Unabridged.Ed Yong takes his readers (or, in my case, listener) into the tiny world of microbes. Traditionally, we think of microbes as tiny invaders that make us sick and, as I sit at home after yet another day of social distancing, it is easy to see it that way.But, Yong takes us into a more complicated world. A world where microbes actually benefit their larger hosts - where microbes can help produce scents or colors for attracting a mate, help guts break down leaves or nuts and even help their hosts survive poisons. In many cases, these microbes and their hosts co-evolved and have become dependent on one another. They have created their own microbiome.But, it's not that simple, either. Sometimes the microbes affect their host's behavior - and not in a good way. They can turn insects into virtual zombies, they can make mice hyperactive or depressed. They can even make mice suicidal (there is a microbe that resides in the guts of cats. It makes mice confuse the smell of cat with the smell of a mouse that is ready to mate. The mouse runs to the cat, gets eaten and the microbe is happily deposited in the gut of a cat. )Yong's real message is...Read more at: https://dwdsreviews.blogspot.com/2020...

Pop science is supposed to make a lot of people smarter. And this book did exactly that. It made me get a better understanding of a very complex topic that is very misunderstood. The book is written in a very accessible and enthusiastic style and makes you want to learn more and more about the microorganisms we all carry around. It's fascinating and in many ways practical. I now know not to waste my money on probiotics and not to exaggerate with cleanliness (though I'll probably get laxer on that once corona is gone). I've learned my bacteria can attract mosquitoes and make me sick. They depend on me and I depend on them, so we should try to get along.But it's not just about people, the book showcases a series of case studies in nature about how bacteria change behaviors, body shapes, and even entire species. I recommend this book to just about anyone, you're bound to find something interesting to you in it.

Your toilet has less harmful microbes on it the longer it sits uncleaned? The less you wash your hands with antibacterial soap or maybe even at all the better? You’d think reading this book would make you want to wash your hands more, or clean your house more. It kindof had the opposite effect. Hmm. I work with wastewater as part of my job. What I read here proves again what I’ve seen from my exposure to this substance for the last decade or so, that my immune system is rock solid. Instead of getting sicker I’ve actually been healthier. I’m not going to swallow pills full of other peoples fecal material like they talk about in this book, but hey everybody has limits! A must read for you science nerd types.. I include myself in that category.

Reading this, I felt sorry for my germophobe friends, for there is no escaping microbes. You can't run; you can't hide! From a footnote in the first chapter: "It's estimated that every human contains 100 trillion microbes, most of which live in our guts. By comparison, the Milky Way contains between 100 million and 400 million stars." We drop them off and pick them up continually. We trail clouds of microbes as we come. All animals do. It's amazing to consider we are but a very small subset of life on this planet. I can only imagine how Leeuwenhoek felt when he first gazed on these tiny "animalcules."The pace of discovery with regard to genetics has been breathtaking lately, and the application to microbial life is exciting. The symbiotic relationship between animals and their microbiome is amazing. However, I wouldn't go so far as to say that "microbes subvert our notions of individuality." (p. 24) That struck me as reductionistic. We're surely more than the sum of cellular processes, bacterial or otherwise.Note well: if your habit is to read over lunch, as is mine, this book selection might better be reserved for another time. Yes, you will be reading about fecal transplants! Fascinating, though.

Good but annoying. This is a tough book to review. The topic is interesting as I don’t have more than a basic understanding of microbes. The pacing was ok, no real wasted words or sections here. But, the writing often set my teeth on edge…especially at the beginning…I almost gave up on the book then and there. But, it got mostly better. However, the bad poetry writing cropped up enough to annoy me and spoil parts of the rest of the book. Still, I learned quite a bit about microbes and their impact on the world. So, while my expectations were met info wise, the writing was disappointing. That said, I give this book a 3. It’s got good info and is interesting, but the writing is distractingly bad at times and spoils the book for me. Maybe if those sections had been better written/edited this would have gotten a 4.

We've always been told to clean ourselves and the surroundings to get rid of microbes, as microbes cause diseases. That statement is only partly true. But the idea of getting rid of all the microbes around us is thought that needs to be reevaluated. Ed Yong in this book provides a fresh perspective towards microbes, with fascinating (and sometimes gross) experiments and facts about how all animals and plants have evolved to work along with microbes to build immunity, digest foods they otherwise can't digest, avoid and cure diseases. We are so dependent on microbes for our survival that even the milk that humans produce for babies contains components to nurture our gut bacteria. However, the old school thought has led to abuse of anti-biotics and hyper-sanitation leading to the destruction of friendly microbes, an increase in inflammatory diseases, and superbugs! There are only a few microbes that are pathogens, while the majority are a necessary part of the ecosystem, some of which are actively leveraged as probiotics, be it to improve digestion or neutralize mosquitos from spreading diseases. We live in a world of microbes, and we're a world of microbes. P.S. Occasionally, a few topics fail to hold your attention, but the book rewards patience with lots of interesting facts again.

Who knew microbes were so interesting? I probably understood only 75% of this content (and will retain even less), but I was thoroughly entertained throughout the entire book. Why do mosquitoes prefer some people and not others? What can probiotics really do for us? How have these microbes and bacteria shaped our planet for billions of years? The author does a great job of breaking down the science jargon into something comprehensible (and occasionally funny).(Note: The audio book was excellent. Would love to listen to it a second time to get an even better understanding of the material.)

Review coming. Lots to say about this book because there is so much information to take in. I'm glad I bought it because I'll refer back to chapters for sure.I started researching gut inflammation and the microbiome in 2011 when IBS hit hard. All the research I was looking at during that time for the massive bouts of joint inflammation I had pointed to gut health and I considered some very drastic measures to try and change things.I changed my diet completely to try and bring some of the inflammation down naturally and I'm still learning and fine tuning to avoid a full blowout of IBD.Every person is uniquely different. This helped me understand the mind/gut connection and has given me more ideas for research. Fascinating stuff in this gem of a book. I will be posting more on this review once I get my notes in order.

Took me around 3 months to finish. But it doesn't mean the work Ed Yong has put in to introduce us to the microworld is not comment worthy. Initially seeing that the book came from a scientific writer and not from a scientist itself made me a little sceptic to go on.. But i think he made me understand that his writing is non biased which a scientist's work cud have been because he/she definitely would have tried to forward his/her outlook while Yong took in to consideration every aspect of the subject. A must read if u want to understand the life on earth at its full capacity.... after reading this when u say "me" u will be meaning something different than what u meant before..

I won’t pretend that I understood every sentence in this book about the fascinating and omnipresent world of microbes. But I really enjoyed it! I don’t think I ever grasped just how much microbes influence animal and human behavior and biology. Or how much we depend on them for good health. This isn’t all about humans either - really interesting stuff about corals, frogs, insects, and all kinds of other wildlife. I recommend both the audio book and the paper version. I had to switch from one to the other midway.

I think it’s important every once in a while to read a book that reminds you how much you don’t know. This book was definitely a little over my head in some parts, and I don’t think I would have gone through it if I hadn’t gotten it on audiobook. I am really glad I read it though, and I was truly fascinated by the microbial world within us that literally keeps us alive every single day. I especially loved the sections that talked about the microbial properties of human milk and how mothers pass on their microbiome to their babies.

Pitched as a book that would do for microbes what Dawkins did for genes, it doesn't quite hit that mark. Along with moments that can be both enlightening and frightening, there are parts of the book that feel mundane and trying too hard to be extraordinary. It's does succeed at being an easily digestible exploration of a field that is poorly understood and, as the book makes clear, unfairly maligned. You will learn a lot.

If you are looking for some nerdy book to lullaby you to sleep - this book most definitely ain’t it. As a person, who had a basic ‘there’s good and bad bacteria’ knowledge, I was glued to the book, soaking in the most jaw-dropping, on occasion discussing, newest findings on the lives of bacteria and the massive influence they posses over their hosts. It’s a science book wrapped up in the most beautiful metaphors. So not only did it open up a whole exciting world of partnerships and treacheries of microorganisms, but it also made for a smooth and, I’d say, pretty romantic literature.

Ecstatic nerdy eloquent science writing about tiny creatures that live everywhere and touch everything. If you watched that Northern Exposure episode where Maggie and Joel learn about dust mites, it’s that, for 265 pages. So good.

This was so good. I'm not sure what possessed me to put it down nearly two years ago but I'm glad I picked it back up and finished it. Who knew microbes were so completely fascinating? Ed Yong, probably.
Fascinating but above my head and more facts than I can remember. May be deserving of 5*.
i learned a lot from this book, most notably that there's a citrus mealybug bacteria named after the professor i work for!

5 stars for the book. 3 stars for the (audible) audiobook. It feels like they recorded the whole book into two different studios, but the parts were all jumbled up. So the quality of the recording kept changing every 5 minutes.
I am not going to shut up about this book for a while. The book and the microbes are mind-blowing, breathtaking, brilliant!!!!

This book contains many fascinating stories about the microbes in our bodies and other animals. Not every chapter was equally interesting and some were way too complicated for me but I definitely found out some exciting and disgusting stuff about these tiny creatures.
Fascinating book and I learned a lot. Quite technical with some of the language which made it a bit of a slow read at times.

I Contain Multitudes is one of the best books I've read so far in the areas of the microbiome/microbiota, genomics, genetics, and evolution. It's a powerful counter to the War on Bacteria and the abuse of antibiotics. Yong is an incredibly skillful writer, knowing just when to deftly balance precise scientific detail with clever humor.

This is a really good book, I learned a lot about microbiome and microbes. But maybe because of the subject matter, I got really bored from time to time and had hard time following the detailed information. You don't have to be a microbiologist to be interested in the topic but I guess being a social scientist prevented me from enjoying the book :/
This book is absolutely incredible. It's relatively hard to read, but so worth it; it will change how you see the world.
So. Good. My friends are glad I’ve finished this book because they think I’ll maybe stfu about it. They’re wrong.

Review: A fascinating story of bacteria cohabitating with humans, plants and other animals. Corrects a myth that we have many more bacteria than our own human cells. Contains numerous examples of symbiosis with bacteria. Suggests that two bacteria combined together and this led to our cells containing mitochondria. Very up to date with the latest developments and interestingly presented.Notes:All eukaryotes pack almost all their DNA into a central nucleus and have mitochondria, which provides cell with chemical energy.It is believed that they were created about 2.5 billion years ago, when bacterium merged with an archaeon. The archaeon provided the chassis of the eukaryotic cell while the bacterium eventually transformed into the mitochondria. Our genomes contain genes that have an archaeal and bacterial character.The latest estimates suggest that we have around 30 trillion human cells and 39 microbial ones. Our cells carry between 20 to 25 thousand genes, but microbes inside us contain around 500 times more.The bacteria don’t physically reshape the gut themselves. Instead they teach the gut cells how to use their own genes to make a healthy gut. This has been demonstrated with mice and gut bacterium called Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron.The stomach bacterium Helicobacter pylori causes ulcers, but also protects against oesophageal cancer.The soil-dwelling microbe called Bacillus thuringiensis produces toxins that can kill insects by punching holes in their guts. Farmers explored it since 1920 by spraying it onto crops.A cut or bruise can split some of our cells apart and spill fragments of mitochondria into our blood – fragments that still keep some of their ancient bacterial character. When our immune system spots them, it mistakenly assumes that an infection is under way and mounts a strong defence. This can lead to a lethal condition called systemic inflammatory response syndrome, which can be worse than the original injury.There is a special group of cells, called a bacteriocyte (Greek for bacteria cell), which accommodate bacteria. Up to a fifth of insect species contain them. They can control and use bacteria to their own good.Viruses called bacteriophages (literally ‘eaters of bacteria’), or phages for short, look like the lunar lander and can be found in our intestines. They keep our microbes in check.The bacteria in our gut almost all belong to four major groups, out of hundreds that exist in the wild. They are Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, Actinobacteria, and Proteobacteria.Mitochondria were once free-living bacteria that became permanently enclosed within a larger cell. This process known as endosymbiosis was accepted thanks to Lynn Margulis. She argued that "Natural selection eliminates and maybe maintains, but it doesn't create", and maintained that symbiosis was the major driver of evolutionary change.Unlike us, bacterias can transfer their DNA horizontally between each others. They can also absorb bits of DNA in their environment left by their dead or decaying neighbours. They can even rely on viruses to move genes from one cell to another. The horizontal gene transfer (HGT) allows bacteria to evolve at great speed. They don’t have to wait for the right mutations to slowly amass within their existing DNA. This leads to development of superbugs, protected against powerful antibiotics.In 2001, when the first full draft of human genome was published, it was found that of the thousands of genes identified, 223 were shared with bacteria but not with other complex organisms. They were probably present in some very early organisms and then lost in later lineages.The presence of Akkermansia muciniphilia in our gut correlates with a lower risk of obesity and malnutricion. The Bacteroides fragilis and Faecalibacterium prausnitzii are anti-inflammatory bugs helping our immune system.Substances that selectively nourish beneficial microbes are called prebiotics.

I haven't been able to stop talking about this book since I started it. This shit is endlessly fascinating (pun intended). I listened to this one, and the narration reminded me of Economist audio editions: a posh Englishman narrating with equal parts enthusiasm and deadpan delivery (did he just substitute re-poopulate for FMT? Yes, yes he did). If genes are the instructions, microbes are the conductors and composers of our lives. They control and coordinate EVERYTHING, and yet we know precious little about how all of this goes down. But there is indication that microbes may be the key to any number of physical and mental ailments - and why not? Contrary to popular myth, there are no good or bad bacteria - bacteria simply act according to the ecosystems and conditions around them. While nobody yet knows which combinations and compositions of microbes are ideal (if there even is an "ideal"), diversity is key. And personally, I'm grateful for all of the dirt I swallowed as a little one. For now, you are what you eat - so eat your fiber and vegetables. Yong is a pop sci writer extraordinare, with an ability to personify microbes and bring to life the quirky scientists that have devoted their lives to this study. I'm convinced this should be turned into a graphic novel, Avengers style, but featuring BACTERIA. In the meantime, just read this.

I found the extensive information about microbes interesting. The authors balanced view, and acknowledgement of the limitations in our knowledge was appreciated. At the same time, the limited knowledge detracted from my enjoyment. I couldn't achieve the authors level of enthusiasm, when so much seemed to boil down to speculation. Still, I learned somethings and it allowed me to mentally masticate on thoughts of complex relationships."A well-functioning partner-ship could easily be seen as a case of reciprocal exploitation. Both partners may benefit there's this inherent tension. Symbiosis is conflict." - Toby Kiers as quoted in the book. I love reading about complex systems. Much of what we are, and experience, is the emergent property of complex systems. The interaction between our cells and the microbes that make up our body, is both fascinating and awe-inspiring to me. Plus, it was nice to get into some biology for a change. I enjoyed learning about the difference between eukaryotes and bacteria, and of the existence of archaea. Of particular interest was microbial relationships and the way our bodies manage bacteria. This sparked a lot of thoughts about society at large. But, more about that later, first…Mucus! I hadn't appreciated exactly how primordial this stuff is. We experience it mostly as something gross, or funny, maybe even erotic. But, this amazing substance is an invention from the dawn of life itself. A product of the struggle between the components of life - usually a barrier for keeping bacteria out. In super hero lore this would be a most powerful ancient relic. One of a handful of special forces preventing evil from destroying all life as we know it.Talking about societies attitude, the book uses the metaphor of a Park Ranger as an alternative to the traditionally combative approach for dealing with bacteria. This resonated with me on a larger philosophical and social level. "Yeah! We should stop thinking about wars, period. And, start acting like stewards to all of mankind. And, get rid of borders and countries. Let's mingle and cooperate, not fight.", is how my inner voice spun off on a tangent. Interestingly I then immediately felt an increased kinship towards the book and its author. Later this amused me - How crazy is it that a perceived moral alignment would impact on my feelings towards a book about microbes. And, that’s why virtue signalling is a thing.But it wasn't just the bias that I was subject too, my entire thought pattern was fallacious. Metaphors are useful but always limiting. It's crazy to think that microbe colonies could be used as an effective model for human societies. It's so natural to latch on to something as supporting evidence of one's own belief system, without out questioning the rational.Fortunately if I hadn't caught myself, the book would have set me straight. Turns out there is no such thing as perfect harmony, even in this most ancient of life's crevices. As the book puts it symbiosis is conflict. In microbiology, every cooperative relationship is a struggle for survival, a delicate balancing act, only coincidentally magnanimous, and never far from outright conflict. I found that a sobering thought.

I recommend this book to everyone, especially the germaphobes, in my circle. While it wasn’t an easy read, by any stretch, I enjoyed this book on so many levels. I love science and respect what scientists do. Their passion is infectious, pardon the pun. Ed Yong is an excellent writer and his use of humour helps make the various chapters accessible. And speaking of chapters, I loved how he packaged them so handily and with clever titles to help make sense of his objective for each one. I especially loved the chapter titled In Sickness and In Health, for its focus on the human biome, but really, the whole book was fascinating. I’ll never think of microbes as evil again. This book has restored my wonder in all living things visible and invisible.
